Class CurveMath

java.lang.Object
  ch.ethz.rtc.kernel.CurveMath

public class CurveMath
extends java.lang.Object

CurveMath provides methods to do mathematics with curves.

maxVDist

public static double maxVDist(Curve a,
                              Curve b)
Computes the maximum vertical distance between a and b. The result equals the maximum y-value of the Curve sub(a, b). If the long-term slope of a is bigger than the one of b, the result is Double.POSITIVE_INFINITY

Parameters:
a - the first Curve.
b - the second Curve.
Returns:
the maximum vertical distance between a and b.
Proposed Rating:
Yellow (wandeler@tik.ee.ethz.ch)
Accepted Rating:
none
JUnit Rating:
Yellow (wandeler@tik.ee.thz.ch)

Computes the maximum vertical distance between a and b. The result equals the maximum y-value of the Curve sub(a, b). If the long-term slope of a is bigger than the one of b, the result is Double.POSITIVE_INFINITY

maxHDist

public static double maxHDist(Curve a,
                              Curve b)
Computes the maximum horizontal distance between a and b. The result equals the maximum y-value of the Curve sub(inv(b), inv(a)). I.e. the results equals the maximum distance when starting at Curve a, and going horizontally to the right until hitting Curve b. If the long-term slope of a is bigger than the one of b, the result is Double.POSITIVE_INFINITY.

The following conditions must be true for the passed parameters:

  • a and b must be wide-sense increasing

Parameters:
a - - the first curve.
b - - the second curve.
Returns:
the maximum horizontal distance between a and b.
Throws:
java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - - if the parameters do not fulfill the specified conditions.
Proposed Rating:
Yellow (wandeler@tik.ee.ethz.ch)
Accepted Rating:
none
JUnit Rating:
Yellow (wandeler@tik.ee.thz.ch)

maxHDistLine

public static Vector maxHDistLine(Curve a,
                                  Curve b)
Computes the maximum horizontal distance between a and b. The result equals the maximum y-value of the Curve sub(inv(b), inv(a)). I.e. the results equals the maximum distance when starting at Curve a, and going horizontally to the right until hitting Curve b. If the long-term slope of a is bigger than the one of b, the result is Double.POSITIVE_INFINITY.

The following conditions must be true for the passed parameters:

  • a and b must be wide-sense increasing

Parameters:
a - - the first curve.
b - - the second curve.
Returns:
the maximum horizontal distance between a and b as a vector.
Throws:
java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - - if the parameters do not fulfill the specified conditions.
Proposed Rating:
Yellow (wandeler@tik.ee.ethz.ch)
Accepted Rating:
none
JUnit Rating:
Yellow (wandeler@tik.ee.thz.ch)

maxPlusConv0

public static Curve maxPlusConv0(Curve c)
Computes maxPlusConv(c, 0), but more efficiently. maxPlusConv0(c)(Delta) = sup_{0<=delta<=Delta} {c(delta)} I.e. the result must be positive and strictly increasing.

Parameters:
c - the Curve.
Returns:
maxPlusConv(c, 0)
Proposed Rating:
Yellow (wandeler@tik.ee.ethz.ch)
Accepted Rating:
none
JUnit Rating:
Yellow (wandeler@tik.ee.thz.ch)

maxPlusDeconv0

public static Curve maxPlusDeconv0(Curve c)
Computes maxPlusDeconv(c, 0), but more efficiently. maxPlusDeconv0(c)(Delta) = inf_{0<=delta} {c(Delta + delta)} maxPlusDeconv0(c)(Delta) = inf_{Delta<=delta} {c(delta)}

Parameters:
c - the Curve.
Returns:
maxPlusDeconv(c, 0)
Proposed Rating:
Yellow (wandeler@tik.ee.ethz.ch)
Accepted Rating:
none
JUnit Rating:
Yellow (wandeler@tik.ee.thz.ch)

ceil

public static Curve ceil(Curve c)
Computes the ceil of a curve. The ceil of a curve is a piecewise constant curve that is built by taking the ceil of the curve at every point on the positive x-axis.

Parameters:
c - the curve to compute the ceil of.
Returns:
a curve that correspond to the ceil of c.
Proposed Rating:
Yellow (wandeler@tik.ee.ethz.ch)
Accepted Rating:
none
JUnit Rating:
Yellow (wandeler@tik.ee.thz.ch)

floor

public static Curve floor(Curve c)
Computes the floor of a curve. The floor of a curve is a piecewise constant curve that is built by taking the floor of the curve at every point on the positive x-axis.

a curve that correspond to the floor of c.
